Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to the different treatments using computer-generated block randomization (block of six).

Participants.evidence: Between May 2021 and December 2021, we treated 165 adult patients for trigger finger at an academic university hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Splinting involved the patient wearing a fixed metacarpophalangeal joint orthosis... Steroid injection was performed using 1 mL of 1% lidocaine without epinephrine and 1 mL of triamcinolone acetonide (10 mg/mL).

Objective.evidence: Are there differences in pain reduction and functional improvement in adults with trigger finger treated with splinting alone, steroid injection alone, and a combination of splinting and steroid injection at 6, 12, and 52 weeks after the intervention?

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes evaluated were VAS pain reduction and improvement in Michigan Hand Outcomes Questionnaire (MHQ) scores at 6, 12, and 52 weeks after the intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to the different treatments using computer-generated block randomization (block of six). Sequentially numbered, opaque, sealed envelopes were used in the allocation concealment process.

Blinding.evidence: Both the allocator and the outcome assessor were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: After screening, 120 patients were randomized to receive either splinting (n = 43), steroid injection (n = 40), or splinting plus steroid injection (n = 37).

Number_Analysed.evidence: An intention-to-treat analysis was performed with all 120 patients, and a per-protocol analysis was conducted with 86 patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There were no clinically important differences in VAS pain scores among the three treatment groups at any timepoint, in either the intention-to-treat or the per-protocol analyses.
